metadata.notes: A classic homiletic structure moving from narrative exposition to moral application.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The sermon shifts in §4 to a demanding tone. It uses rhetorical questions to challenge the listener's identity and 'musts' regarding imitation.
quotes: How can you assume a name which neither your works nor your nature authenticates?
How can you flatter yourself with the title of 'son' when you don’t prove sonship...?

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The preacher provides comfort by lowering the bar for entry at the end, ensuring the 'child' feels the task is achievable.
quotes: Reject such empty pretexts, for a small donation will earn you a magnificent reward.

adult.analysis: The first half is an objective analysis of the text. However, the 'Adult' is sidelined in the application phase in favor of a Parent-Child dynamic.
quotes: He divided his entire fortune into two parts: one to perform works of mercy, the other to right all the wrongs...

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The listener is pressured to 'prove' their sonship through works, triggering the Adapted Child's fear of not belonging or being a 'fraud'.
quotes: If you want to belong to your Father, do like Zacchaeus...
two persons wouldn’t bear the same name if their deeds were diametrically opposite.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a brief moment of 'joy' mentioned, but it is a prescribed joy ('quake with joy') rather than spontaneous.
quotes: Praise God and quake with joy, Zacchaeus...

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher acts as the authoritative interpreter and moral judge, placing the congregation in the position of the student/child who must prove their worth.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Social: 'Let us look at Zacchaeus.' Psychological: 'You are not living up to the name of Christian unless you give money.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'Bait and Switch' from the grace shown to Zacchaeus to the demands placed on the listener creates a double bottom where 'salvation' is actually 'earned'.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of 'boundless generosity' and 'divine blessing' seen in Zacchaeus.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire to be a 'son of God' and fear of being a 'fraud'.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The shift from Jesus seeking Zacchaeus to the listener having to 'prove sonship' by works.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels the weight of obligation; the preacher maintains moral authority.

evidence_quotes: Zacchaeus deserved the name... because his will was conformed to God’s.
How can you flatter yourself with the title of 'son' when you don’t prove sonship...?

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. Offers the 'small donation' as the easy way to 'merit' the reward.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium. Questions the authenticity of the listener's faith and nature.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim (inadequate/short) who needs to be Rescued by following the preacher's instructions.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Minimal. The sermon concludes with a command rather than an invitation to Adult reflection.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon begins with a beautiful narrative (Adult/Free Child) but devolves into a Critical Parent/Adapted Child dynamic. It creates a psychological 'bind' where the listener's identity as a child of God is contingent upon performance. While it offers a 'low bar' for entry (a cup of water), the underlying logic is one of merit and proof rather than unconditional grace, potentially fostering a 'guilt-compliance' cycle in the listener.
strengths: Vivid narrative description of the biblical scene.
Encourages practical altruism (giving to the poor).
areas_for_improvement: The shift from 'grace' to 'merit' is psychologically jarring.
The use of shaming rhetorical questions ('How can you flatter yourself...').
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try moving to an Adult-Adult transaction. Instead of asking 'How can you call yourself a son?', ask 'In what ways does Zacchaeus's joy spark a desire for generosity in your own life today?' This invites reflection rather than defensive adaptation.
